I hazard life? No, let Valerian come,
To grapple with th' Antagoniſt: who ſlain,
She will abhor my brother for the fact.
But ſay Valerian ſhould be ſlain? what then?
I have th' eſtate, and powerful riches move,
And is the Primum Mobile to Love. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The Coaſt is clear, no lurking Pyrate lies
In wait, no Shelf, nor Rock, nor Quickſand here;
That threatens Shipwrack to my fraighted Bark,
That's bound for Cecilie: I'le put to ſhore.
Yet ſtay: what have we here ſixt on her Door?
Back, back, Valerian, hence, away;
What means this Charm? or what infernal Spell
Is this which ſo conjures Valerian?
Here's no ſafety to be found. I am betraid

l.hi: Where a Champion by my ſide,
Stands to guard me as his Bride?

sp.l: Hum! be what he will, Hector or Hercules;
I dare encounter, Back, back, Valerian? No.
sp.stage: Valerian pulls the Curtain and Cecilie enters.
sp.l: Lady this traverſe muſt no longer, be,
Partition to our Loves, who are as one.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: I come my Lord, why are you thus incens'd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come then, and let me like the amorous vine
About the Elm, enfold thee in mine Armes.
Nay flie not back, maugre thy Magick Spels,
Champion or Devil, Ile not be retrograde.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Keep off, Valerian, touch me not, or die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The intereſt I claim is due by promiſe,
And ratifi'd by Heaven: th' art mine: I muſt
And will enjoy thee.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Stay good my Lord,
But hear me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Oh! Noble Sir,
Be not too raſh: Condemn me not before
You know me guilty.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Speak then, but be ſuccinct.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: I will, and thus a ſecret do unfold.
There is an Angel Guardian of my ſoul
And body too. A glorious powerful wight,
Brighter than Phaebus rayes, when he with all
His luſtre darts his fiery-ſprakling beams.
Whoſe eye like burning lamps reſplendent ſhine.
Whoſe Arms can reach above Olympus height.
Whoſe breath can blaſt, as Northern winds do buds,
An hoaſt of warriers. Dwarfs your Giants were
That fought againſt your Gods, compar'd with him,
Nay more.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, you have ſaid enough: too much,
Beyond belief. But think not thus to ſcare
Valerian with your bugbears. There within
Thy Chamber, thou falſe-hearted Cecily,
Thy Paramour lurks, whom, that he may eſcape,
Thou mak'ſt ſo terrible. Tuſh! I nor fear
His dreadful brow, nor more than humane ſtrength.
This ſword ſhall make a paſſage through his heart:
VVhere ſhould I finde thee, oh! Could my juſt wrath
Forbear to quell what moſt I lov'd till now.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: And may do ſtill my Lord.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Say then, what is he?
But I muſt ſee.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: You ſhall, but if you now,
Now as you are a Pagan, ſhould attempt
To violate by force, He, though unſeen,
Will ſtrike you dead. Which miſchief to prevent,
I beg upon my knees you will forbear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: May I not ſee him?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: He's a Spirit, Sir,
Has no Corporeal ſubſtance, can aſſume
A ſhape ſo dreadfull, As no mortal can Behold.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: All this is but illuſion.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Then, cauſe you'r jealous, ſearch my Chamber round.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I will. Val. ſearches within.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Nay look in every corner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have, and no man finde. Why then th'art chaſte
And true to thy Valerian:

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Heaven knows I am.
And love you 'bove all mortals. Therefore I
Beg on my knees with tears, not to attempt
To bring me to your Bed, and haſten fate,
Which brings a double death: That of your ſoul:
'Tis that my Lord, which makes mine eyes diſtill
Theſe dewy drops, which trickling down my cheeks
From thence aſcend to the Almighty's throne,
To beg of him t'appeaſe and curb your wrath,
And to couſtrain your too much daring hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Thou haſt preval'd but 'tis on this condition
That I may ſee that Angel; and I vow.—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Vow to believe, and joyn with me in faith.
Then ſhall our ſouls be linkt, our loves more chaſte;
And if I ſhew you not that glorious wight,
Say, I am falſe, and my Religion ſuch:
Say I am treacherous both to Heaven and you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I could be curious.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Be not ſo my Lord,
But really proceed, and with deſire,
Of Heaven, which muſt be priz'd above a wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, I am reſolv'd; what then muſt next be done?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: VVill you be ſecret?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As thyne own heart my Dear.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: In Via Appia, which your Lordſhip knows,
Not far from hence, in Vaults within the Earth,
Lye many Chriſtians. 'Mongſt the reſt there's one,
A venerable Man, our holy Biſhop,
Be pleas'd (attended by my man) to go
To him, who will inſtruct you in our Faith:
And when the purifying ſtreams ſhall rinſe,
And cleanſe the Ordures of your tainted ſoul,
Return to me: and then you ſhall behold,
What, next th' eternal power, is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Methinks a light's transfu'sd into my ſoul,
And a more powerfull fire has ſeiz'd upon
My now relenting heart, which do's adde wings
To my deſires, Madam, I take my leave:
Till my return, be what you are.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Still yours.—
'Tis but the hand of Heaven which wounding cures. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Hum! my brother gone, and not ſo much as blood ſhed?
This kill-cow Champion then enjoys her ſtill. Cecily ſings within.
Liſt, ſhe's in triumph, ſinging, and now 'tis
Back back Tiburtius. Fear not; I am not ſo forward
To hazard life or limb for a Miſtris:
Mach leſs for thee who haſt a Paramour.
Expect not then Tiburtius bold attempt.—
Yet, Madam! madam!

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: VVhat's he diſturbs us there?
Is't you my Lord Tiburtius?

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: As you ſee.
But where's Valerian your Lord and Love? ſcar'd hence
By your ſo dreadfull Champion, or your ſpells?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Not ſo, but to return again he's gone.
And when they meet by one ſole interview,
All quarrels ſhall be ended.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Very good.
And who of three ſhall then enjoy your love?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: That ſoon ſhall be diſcover'd by th'event.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Yet one thing ere we part, I fain would know:
By what Enchantment now, while VVinter cloathes
The Earth with ſnow and hoary froſts, ſuch odours
Breath, as if with rich perfume the Lilly
And ſweeter Roſe were by a forward Spring,
Brought forth to yield their pleaſing ſavours, here;
No Flowers I ſee, but Roſes in your Cheeks,
No Lillies, but thoſe Ivory fingers there,
VVhich cannot vent ſuch odoriferous ſents,
As now perfume the Ayre.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Oh Noble Sir,
Think not, we Chriſtians work by Magick art.—
VVith Roſes here, and Lillies intermixt
My temples with a Coronet are wreath'd,
VVhich though you ſee not, we no Sorcery
Have us'd to blinde your eyes, which have a filme
That overſpreads your ſight. Go, go, my Lord;
I pray go to your brother, take his advice;
And then return: then (happy) ſhall you ſee,
The Garland which I wear of fragrant Flowers;
And ſee beſides with him, what I have promis'd.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Madam, your Charm is powerfull; I'le away. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: May Heaven illumine both as he begins,
And born again ſhall be theſe Noble Twins. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Almachius, Saphricius, Officers, and Headſman with an Axe.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: COme bring him forth, I'le ſee the Execution;
Or if he yet relent and ſacrifice
Unto our gods, he's pardon'd.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: To your gods?
Your Devils, Monſters, Moppets, Puppets, Bugges.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Out thou blaſphemous wretch! away with him.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: I have endur'd a torture in each joynt:
Theſe feet were ſcorch'd, theſe arms with burning torches:
Yet could I ſuffer more.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Take him away.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: O! let me come; 'tis more than time to ſpeak,

l.hi: Saphricius! Saphricius!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: What's hee
That interrupts our Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Nic.

l.hi: Saphricius,

sp.l: I once was thy dear friend, and thou we'rt mine,
Untill (unfortunate) we fell at jarres,
And open enmity, yet now at leaſt
Forgive, as I do thee.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Forgive thee? no.
Thou too injurious wer't to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Say all the fault were mine, and only you
Were injur'd, yet now deſtin'd as a Victim
And ſacrifice for Heaven, what Heaven commands
For Heaven's ſake do not omit.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: I never will forgive thee.
He troubles me here.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Come Sirrah, ſtand aſide.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pardon; upon my knees I beg it; forgive me Good Saphricius.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: What an abſurd fellow art thou?
VVhat need'ſt fear him, he's going to die.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Oh there's a Power above; all Charity,
All Goodneſs, Love; for which he gives his life,
To which his ſoul relates, and muſt be like,
In rendring good for ill, and pardoning all:
Therefore upon my knees, again I beg it.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Away thou hatefull and injurious man,
Nor I, nor Heaven, will pardon thy offence.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Here proſtrate on the earth, I kiſs your feet,
Though you likewiſe I thought had wronged me;
Yet be the fault all mine, forgive me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Not I: this fellow vexes me.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Alma.
sp.p: Force him to ſilence there, or ſtop his mouth.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Now prepare: y'are come to th' place aſſign'd.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Aſſign'd for what?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: For Death, by this keen Axe.
Becauſe thou wilt not offer ſacrifice
To Jupiter;

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: So, is't for that cauſe, then—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Executioner do your Office. Saphr. trembles.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I will my Lord
Inſtantly. The valiant Saphricius,
Who late endur'd all kinde of Tortures, now
Begins to tremble every joynt and limbe.
I'le cure him of his Palſey.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Hold, ah! hold
Thy hand, my friend, and hear one word.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: What's that?
For two thou ſhalt not have, what is it?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p: Gods.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Speak that again.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Unto the Gods I ſay,
I'le ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: VVhat ſays he there, of Gods?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: That he to them will ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Diſcover
Too I will, what now a Chriſtian Lady
Is perpetrating 'gainſt two Noble Lords.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Thou haſt thy life: The gods are mercifull,

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: My Lord! my Name's Nicephorus.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: What's next?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I am a Chriſtian too, and what this Renegade
sp.l: Has loſt, I come to gain; a Palm of Victory.
A Crown immortall.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Art thou then a Chriſtian?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: I ſay, I am; and were it poſſible
VVould give another life, ſo that I might
Reclaym him there who has renounc'd his Faith
For want of Love: the badge a Martyr brings,
Elſe cannot have the honour to be ſuch.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Gaoler, take him to your cuſtody. And to morrow
(If he recant not, as his fellow has done)
Executioner you know your Office, let him dye.
I muſt away: affairs which much import
Are calling on me. Come Saphricius
I go to offer Incenſe to great Jove; Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.p:
I'le joyn with you my Lord moſt willingly.
Manet Niceph. & Execut.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: He's gone; O miſerable man! he's loſt
For ever loſt, I fear. Suffer'd ſo much?
So long! and at the laſt apoſtatize.— ay me!
Have you not well obſerv'd the Provence Roſe,
How every leaf pluckt from the Neighbouring Chives,
Is tipt as 'twere with Gold? Such are our actions,
Such our thoughts; when golden Charity
And Love dos guild our every leavy thought,
Sprung from the ſoul: elſe nought avails, nor death,
Without the hearty love of friend and Foe:
He onely dyeth well, that's living ſo.— Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Valerian and Tiburtius come out of the Vault, Urban appearing to the middle above the Vault.

sp.speaker: Urban.
sp.l: MY Lord Valerian (twice the elder Son
By birth and Faith) you'l have a ſpecial care
Of him that ſeconds you, your only brother,
Who leſs inſtructed, cauſe the time was ſhort,
Next that of Heaven t'aſſiſt, wants your ſuppport.—
You are my children now, and ſheep: farewell.
Doubt not the Lady wil fulfill her word.
Remember now y'are Combatants for Heaven:
And that your Guerdon, an immortal Crown,
Is that you fight for; not for fading wreathes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For this Atchievement we entreat your Prayers.

sp.speaker: Urban.
sp.l: Nor I in that, nor in paternal care
Will be defective, Heaven bleſs my Children. Deſcends.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where we have been, what ſeen, and what acquir'd;
Our breſts may better lodge than we can utter.
W'have been in Paradiſe, beheld a Heaven
I'th bowels of the earth: the Chriſtian Flock
Within a Fold, whoſe darkneſs is exil'd,
As well b' exemplar life, as burning Lamps.
Here ſome in Prayers, there others chaunting Hymns.
Here ſome in Contemplation.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Others I ſaw
And heard exhorting to a vertuous life,
And ſome inſtructing Catechumens, ſuch
As prepare themſelves for holy tincture.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not mine and thine is heard amongſt them there,
But all in common, all one heart, one will:
Unanimous they live. VVhy now methinks
I am arm'd 'gainſt all events.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could pull down Idols, and deſtroy their Fanes:
O! what a greeting will there be betwixt
That vertuous Lady and our new born ſelves?
Madam I come, I flye with wings of Love,
One ſoul with thine, one heart and faith I bring,
Now touch thy Organ, and melodious ſing.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: But heark, my Lord, ere we ſet forward,—
I am deceiv'd if I ſee not ſome here in Via Appia,
Are wont to lie in wait for Chriſtians.
1. Come my Maſters, keep your ſtanding.
2. I ſee two of 'hem.
3. Then let's comprehend 'hem.
1. No, we'le reſpect 'hem till they come within
Reach, and then down with 'hem.
2. No, no, let's dog 'hem home, and beſet the houſe.
3. That we may do by the ſent; for I ſmell them already,
Th' are ſo muskifyed;
1. I follow 'hem cloſe. So, ſo, when they're hous'd Have at 'hem, then, hah for a Booty. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Flavia, and Marcus, Anguſta, Metricio, Phantaſio, Palinodio.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: A Nguſtula, come ye hither.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Tell me, when was your Ladie's bed laſt made?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Madam, upon the Marriage day i'th morning

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: And never ſmce? Mar. looks within.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Not ſince indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis even ſo: Nay worſe, for 'tis yet made.
Ay me! here's no body. Ah! that bodeing! ſomebody
Has deceiv'd us VVife. This a Nuptial bed?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Nay, not ſo much as tumbled on. VVhy where?
VVhere lay my Daughter all this while.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Alas!
Good Lady! if he came not to bed, was't
Her fault? In former times (I know it well)
She often watch'd all night: ſpent it in prayer:
But now what Lady could have been ſo godly?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I am vext.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And ſo am I.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Nay I am
Aſham'd to ſee't, wed and not bed together!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now Sir, you with your Epithalamiums, To Met.
Your Epigrams, Anagrams, Chronograms,
Your Raptures, Enthuſiaſmes, and Whim-whams.
To humour my Daughter, with your Melancholy
Strains, that now ſhe's fit for no-thing, nor no-
-Body, that I ſee; And you with your Dia- To Phan.
-Paſons, and brain-ſick Crotchets! you have run
A fair diviſion, have you not, to ſeparate
Man and VVife? And you Gentleman-uſher. To Pal.
That look ſo wilde: you that have been rambling—
And now come ſcar'd out of your little wits,
VVhat newes? what's the matter with you now?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: A matter of matters, nay all my back and ſides
Had been Matter, but that Noble Tiburtius came
To ſuccour me. Otherwiſe I had been ſtript and whipt,
Onely for ſaying my Lady was as fair as Venus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But where's my Lord Valerian?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: He'le be here
This night, or to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: To morrow morning, will
That be a fit time to viſit his wife, Goodman Palinodie?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Why then to Night Madam, he'le be here. money Both give him Exeunt Mar. & Fla.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Thou'rt welcome then, here's thy reward. —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And here; come Flavia let's prepare.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Poet and Muſitian, look here.Shews the money. Will you participate? No.
'Tis ſtrange a Poet that ſtands ſo much on feet,
Should fall into wants: Or that a Muſitian
Should not live as well on good aires, as a Sycophant
By an ill breath; but nothing ſtrange that this
Gentleman-UſherKiſſes his hand, and congies. by this, and this, is richly clad
In pluſh here.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yet that you may not ſing with heavy heart
For both your Muſes, go, I have a quart.

div.head: ACT. V. Scene 1.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: FEar, with belief, unpowers: diſarmes me now
Who late was daring, while (an unbeliever;)
I could not credit what by faith I've learn'd,
That there are Spirits call'd Intelligences,
On whoſe Majeſtick brow a terrour dwells. —
The gentle plaites I dare not now unfold,
Who once could like a violent torrent ruſh
Into her Chamber. Might I ſee Her firſt,
Whoſe countenance is angelical, from thence
Mine eye might be transferr'd, though fearfully

To view her Angel.
Enter Devil.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: Here I am: look then,
On me; an Angel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But not hers, thou art
So monſtrous, ugly, and deform'd.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.l: I am.
And that I may evict belief from thee,
A Maſque of Ladies, Devils & Satyrs. The Dance ended, when Valerian draws the Curtain, they all vaniſh, and Cecilie enter.See Nymphs and Ladies here which I command,
As fair as thine: Mine rather might have ſaid,
For when ſhe's ſlumbring in her bed, I ſtand
And gently fold in mine, her lilly hand.
Which nimbly now ſhall touch the Organ: and,
While that, and other Muſick ſounds; t'advance
The power I have, I here command a Dance. They dance.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord, my deareſt Love and Spouſe.
What means this ghaſtly look? what is't you fear?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They're vaniſh'd all with him, who ſtanding there
Told me, he was thine Angel; but ſo ugly,
I could not think a beauty had commerce
With ſuch a monſter.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: No; my Lord, 'twas he
Who oppoſite to my bleſt Guardian, ſeeks
To ruin that, the other do's preſerve.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But here were Ladies too.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: But airy Phantoſmes:
Deluding Devils, they who can aſſume
What ſhape they liſt: yet ſtill are limited
In that, and power by the Almighty's will

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And yours it ſeems; for at th' approach of day,
As the black Negra Night with Ravens wings
Poſts from the Confines of the Univerſe,

So did at your aſpect, theſe ſpirits vaniſh. —
Enter Angel with two wreaths of flowers, made of Lilies and Roſes.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: My Lord, I need not be inquiſitive to know
What now you are: this object ſhall ſuffice
To tell how faith has clear'd your gloomy eyes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But not ſo eagle-ſighted yet am I
As to behold this glorious wight.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Yet, but
A ray, or glimpſe of the immortal power.

sp.speaker: Angel.
sp.l: Hail to you Virgin, and your happy Spouſe,
Bleſt be your Loves, which heaven has linkt in one.
I come from you bright Manſion, Paradice;
From thence have brought theſe fragrant wreaths of flowers
The pure white Lilly and the crimſon Roſe
That, to denote your ſpotleſs, chaſter Loves;
This, to preſent the ardour of your flames,
Which upward tend towards th' immortal fire.
Bow, bow yourheads, while croſſe-wiſe thus I crown,
To ſymbolize, you muſt ſtoop low to riſe.
And like the Palme be preſt; for with renown,

Without Afflictions Croſſe, is gain'd no Crown.
Enter Tiburtius and kneels.

div.l: Here yet a Crown expects a Champions head,
Who in his firſt (as he was born from Earth)
Come's now to joyn, bleſt by a ſecond birth.
Joyn Arm in Arm as you enwombed lay, The brothers embrace.
A loving pair, yet happier twins too day.

l.hi: So from the Brook return the bathed Doves,
while from your candid breaſt ſpring purer Loves.
So from the waters waſhd, we may behold
The pure white ſheep return unto the fold,
So in the dewy Morn, we ſee the Larkes
So fraighted come a pair of wave-waſh'd Barkes.
Then welcome Doves with chaſter Loves.
Welcome enroll'd Sheep in the fold,
Mount pair of Larkes, and for your Barkes,
Heaven be your Haven: ne're disband,
Here caſt your Anchor, Hope; and Land.

sp.speaker: Angel
sp.l: Time calls away to mount bove liquid skies,
Be arm'd, prepare, a ſudden ſtorm will riſe
Loſe not your Sea-mark Heaven, but boldlyſteer.—
The Tempeſt paſt, dark clouds ſhall diſappear;
Next, Day eternal ſhine; Bleſt three adieu,—
None ſhall behold your wreatths, but ſuch as you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come then Diſaſters, Fire, and Sword, and Racks.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: Come what can come, what ſpiteful hell can belch,
Or Heaven ſhall pleaſe to ſend, or ſhall permit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Or come whatſoe're it be, as we embrace,
We'le hug their torments. What is't once to die,
To live ſo many lives, eternally?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: My dear Valerian, now, as fully mine,
As I am yours, and both linkt to a third,
Your deareſt brother: ſummon'd now by heaven
To be ingulf'd in a tempeſtuous Mayne,
Let's to his Standard flie, who now invites
His ſouldiers to a Combate. His pure-white
Of Innocence, and flowing purple, tells,
Ours muſt be like, although no parallels.

div.head: SCENE 2.
div.stage: Enter Almachius, and Officers, Maximus and Attendants.

sp.speaker: 1 Off.
sp.p: There my Lord; thoſe two we dog'd from Via Appia.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Valerian and Tiburtius Chriſtians? I thought as much.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But not ſo much as we can act of Chriſtians.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Nor could I think ſo much of Sorcery,
As can this younger Lady actuate:
Lay hold of her and thoſe her two Diſciples.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: VVhat have we here to do? Diſturb me in My own houſe?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: And carry hence your Daughter too,
That's more; for Juſtice has no limit. Take her Away.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It ſhall not need my Lord: I paſſe
My word, ſhe ſhall be forth coming.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Nay here,
Your houſe is ample, we can ſoon diſpatch.
Let firſt the Brothers come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: VVe rather flie,
T'embrace the worſt of deaths thou canſt invent.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Y'are Noble; adore our mighty Gods, and live.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: That were t'offend th' Almighty Power of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: You know the penalty, to loſe your goods, Confiſcate.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Goods? They are but breeding evils:
But now disburs'd amongſt the poor, a treaſure laid up in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I there ſhe ſtands who Wrought this policy,
VVe'l come to hear the fource of all this miſchief.
Mean while (my Lords) you (to reſolve) retire,
Either t'adore the Gods, or be beheaded.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: VVhat two extreams are theſe? Or make a Stock
Or Stone a God (renouncing him above,
t'incur everlaſting death) or die.
This I. —

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: And I embrace.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To die but once.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p: Live ever: Thus I am reſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Then take 'hem hence. Exeunt Val. & Tib.
Bring in the Lady.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: She's here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Sitting down.] Cecile, thou art here arraign'd for hainous crimes,
Which who could think were lurking in a breaſt
So young and tender? In a Damoſel fair,
And by extraction Noble? But when Vice
Uſurpes a hold in better Natures, ſoon
They are deprav'd, like richer wines, which once,
Corrupted, taint the Veſſel more where th' are
Enclos'd—So young! yet could'ſt by Magick Art
Enchaunt the Lord Valerian; who enamour'd,
Was by thy powerful and bewitching charmes
Bound in the chains of a prodigious love. —
Then was he wrought upon t'abjure the Gods,
And march among the ſuperſtitious rank
Of ſuch Impoſtors as thy ſelf. — This done,
(For miſchief has no period) you engroſs
His Goods, his Plate, and Jewels: Was content
To feign a Marriage, more t'endear your ſelf,
Though 'twere by proſtitution. Next you were content
He might be publickly traduc'd
For Chriſtianiſme, and now to loſe his head,
With his, as Noble Brother, Lord Tiburtius.
VVho elſe might have enjoy'd his full eſtate.
Laſtly, to cheat the Emperour of his Right,
VVhich comes for want of heir, they have I ſee,
VVhich was a plot of yours) they have no place,
No other Magazine (where they have hid
Their treaſure) but Beggars, Rogues, and Raſcals,
Apoſtates, and ſuch like ſcum of th' earth. —
All's gone, all given away, by which you hope
(Forſooth) to gratifie your poor-born God.
Is not this true, and verified by many
Which I could name; amongſt the reſt Saphricius,
A holy Convert, who was one of yours,
Well vers'd in all your plots. But why ſhould I
Exaggerate, what of it ſelf is ſo,
Enormous? No: I pity Lady your
More tender years, and Noble Parents here:
Pity a beauty which deſerves to be
Enthron'd upon a Princely Seat, rather
Than be ſo vilified, and made ſo baſe
As to conſort with ſordid, deſpicable,
And abject riff-raffe, vipers, vermines, worms,
Which creep in th' earth, and lurk in horrid Caves.
What ſay you Lady, deny? or guilty yield?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: What need I traverſe this Indictment? all
Compacted of untruths? know then I am
A Chriſtian; not therefore baſe; but you
Who in your Gods, do homage to the Devil.
Chriſtian and baſe! O! had I breath enough,
To eccho in the air this glorious Name!
A title 'tis; Encomium, that tranſcends
'Bove humane things; by Chriſtian I am made.
More noble than by birth, more powerful than
Your Caeſars; more victorious. Tell me of Goods?
Gold, Plate, and Jewels! Theſe I more contemn,
Than what I trample on. Unworthy Judge
That call'ſt me proſtitute, I defie
Thee, and thy Goddeſſes, that were but ſuch:
Harlots, and Queans: thy Gods adulterous. Va'erian is my Spouſe; but far more dear
By that which now he is: A Chriſtian.
This our glory, this is our true renown,
To gain by combate an immortal Crown.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Our patience is abus'd, our Gods contemn'd,
To whom, or ſacrifice, or die.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: But die?
Die but one death? muſt I but loſe one life
To purchaſe an eternal? Oh! how good!
How bounteous heaven, which by a quick return,
Renders for death a life for ever happy!

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Bring 'hem forth there; Sha't ſee to what thou'ſt brought

A wretched pair, who late were Noble Lords.
Enter Headſman Val. and Tib. and Cec.
And if good Nature be not utterly
In thee deprav'd, thy more relenting heart
Cannot but have remorſe. See here they come.
Poor Lords? dejected men! that fix on thee
Their heavy eyes, from whence the miſchief ſprang.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Not heavy eyes, not ſad, but chearful, clear;
Made ſuch by the reflexive light of heaven.
My Lords, you my dear Spouſe, and you his brother.
You have th' honour firſt t'inveſt your ſelves
Within the liſts, where I ſhould firſt have been,
Who firſt ſhew'd you the way: but y'have out-ſtript
Your Leader as leſſe worthy, who ſhall be
Happier to trace the manly ſteps you tread.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dear Spouſe and Miſtriſs (not in Venus School,
But that of Heaven) by you we firſt were taught
A leſſon which we now have got by heart:
That humane love is like a coal of fire,
Which lies on th' hearth; but by the mounting flame
A love divine is figur'd, which tranſcends.
Therefore ſalute you with a chaſt embrace.
Farewel dear Spouſe. Embraces her.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Death parts but for a while,
I'le haſten after; that as our bodies bed
In earth-together, our ſouls may reunite.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.l: May I be Paranymph, and lead the way,
Who though I laſt come hither of us two,
May by this birth precede.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: O! force of love!
Or firſt, or laſt, ambitious in deſire
Of heaven, you happy twins ſhall meet again. —
But Lords you ſuffer here, as Kings ſhall reign.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Away with 'hem to th' place of execution.
O! now they're coming back, and will recant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Dear Love adieu.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Dear Spouſe adieu.

sp.speaker: Tib.
sp.p:
We crave your prayers t'aſſiſt us in the way.
Exeunt Val. and Tib. Alm. Peace

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Bleſt be your night that brings eternal day.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Peace, Sorcereſſe, with thy enchaunting tongue.
Or ſmoke ſhall ſtop the paſſage of thy breath.
Fire ſhall conſume thee Witch; take her away; into her own dry bath.
Beſet her round with fagots, and diſſolve
To aſhes that polluted corps. Away with her.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Thus happy may I be, and loſe my breath,
Midſt flames of Love, and die a Phaenix death. Exit with Officers.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Go ſee them beheaded.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: I will, my Lord. Exit Max.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p:
Diſpatch and bring me word.
Enter Marcus and Flavia and kneel.

div.l: Now my Lord Marcus, and my Lady there,
What is't you now petition on your knee?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O! Sorrow, till now, deny'd to give a vent
To my ſurcharged ſoul,

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: What is't you crave?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That th' execution of the law may be Suſpended; our Daughter may be reclaim'd, She's young.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: No, no, you ſhould have had a care

In time: 'tis now too late, ſhe's ſo poyſon'd
Enter Maximus looking up in the air, an Officer following.

div.l: Are the two poppy heads cut from their ſtems?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: Dead th' are, and yet not dead, ſee where, ſee, ſee, Th' are mounting in the air.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: The fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.p: No, no, the glorious ſouls I ſee of that Bleſt pair, Valerian and Tiburtius.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Imaginary Viſions in the air,
Or elſe the Twins Pollux and Caſtor, which
We call Tyndarides.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: No, 'bove the height of the rich ſpangled skies,
Two winged Wights, more bright than ſunny beams,
I ſee tranſporting of their fulgent ſouls. —
Great is Valerian and Tiburtius God.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Yet more Witchcraft?

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: No, the Gods are Devils,
Which have bewitch'd you with their fopperies.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Out upon the Villain! blaſphemous Renegade.
Take him away to burn with the Enchauntreſſe,

If ſhe already be not burn!
Exit Maximus with Officers.

sp.speaker: Headſman.
sp.l: Not burnt my Lord,
The flames at diſtance keep, and dare not touch
So much as that which doth her body veſt.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Yet more ſorcery! why? haſt thou not a ſword
To ſever head from ſhoulders?

sp.speaker: Headſman.
sp.l: Yes my Lord,
Sharp as a razor.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Haſt a vigorous arm?

sp.speaker: Headſm.
sp.l: And dextrous too, to ſlice as from the ſtalke,
A limber Daſie or a Daffadil. —

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Then come with me, I'le be ſpectator. Exeunt Almach. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come Flavia, ſhall we not ſee our daughter?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Our Daughter murther'd? Can the loving Ewe
Behold her tender lamb ſnatch'd from her ſide,
And ſee it ſlaughter'd by the Butchers hand?
I cannot husband, be a cruel witneſs
Of the diſaſterous death of my dear lamb.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If flames could not conſume, why ſhould the ſword,
Be more injurious to an innocent?
Or if her God with a more powerful hand
Could curb the raging fire, why may not he
Contract the Nerves of that more cruel Butcher?
Or arm her Neck againſt the dint of Steel?
sp.stage: Enter Headſman looking on his Sword.
sp.l: But ſee our hopes are vain: She's dead, ſhe's dead,
Behold his murthering Sword beſmear'd with blood.

sp.speaker: Headſman.
sp.l: Hum! what prodigy is this? my Sword's not dull,
Nor was my arm bereav'd of wonted ſtrength,
Why then, while thrice I ſtruck, and thrice my ſword
Had paſſage as I thought 'twixt joynt and joynt;
Why fell not down her mown off tottring head?
Like ice on cragged rock diſſolv'd by heat?
sp.stage: Enter Cecilie lead by her ſervants.
sp.l: See here ſhe comes, what ſoder could ſhe have?
To cement what this ſword dis joynted thrice
Or this is Magick Art, or elſe ſhe has
An Eſculapius 'bove all power of Gods.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lives ſtill our daughter, or by your ſupport
Is ſhe but held?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Breaths ſtill this virgin head,
Which has a languid, yet a ſweet aſpect?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Dear Parents yet I live, could you believe
The fabulous ſtory of your Hercules,
Who ſlic'd off Hydru's heads, which grev again
In number moe, yet not believe your eyes,
VVhich ſee I live, or ears, which hear me ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Still may'ſt thou live, whom now we living ſee.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Still would you have me live? Dos't not ſuffice
That bounteous heaven has granted me three dayes
At my more humble ſuit to intercede
For your Converſion?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Alas what are three dayes
To enjoy a Child?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: This was the boon I begg'd,
That with your leave, this houſe may be transform'd,
And conſecrated to the power above,
To be a Church, where true believers may
Adore their Maker, and by frequent prayer
Appeaſe his wrath, by whoſe permiſſion now
sp.stage: Enter Angel, and ſtands by her.
sp.l: Th'are perſecuted. — Soft! what whiſpering voice
Is that which by prophetick ſpirit tells,
That this my body to be buried here,
Shall (when a thouſand and four hundred years
Are fully paſt and gone) be found entire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, Daughter, might we live till then and ſee it.
I then would be a Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Flae.
sp.p: So would I.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: You would. Ah! Infidelity! when thou
Haſt long been foſtred in a darkſome breaſt,
How hard it is for light to be transfus'd;
Or heat of love into decrepit age?
Happy who young begin to live and love.
Dos't hear Anguſta?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Yes forſooth Madam.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Thou weep'ſt I ſee, there can no richer pearls
Adde liſtre to a virgins face, than tears
VVhich are diſtill'd for expiation of
A fin-ſick ſoul. Tiburtius thou didſt love;
Valeaian was my Spouſe. They are gone before
T'eternal happineſs. I follow myne.
O! may'ſt thou emulate, ſucceed to thyne. Palinodio.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Thou'ſt been
But ſtaggering in thy Faith; ſuiting too much
VVith Palinodie, ready to recant,
When but a whipping menac'd to thy skin
A tranſitory pain.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Madam,
I never lov'd ſuch tranſitory things,
Which by the world entic'd or threaten'd me.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Thou'ſt been my Gentleman-uſher.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yes forſooth,
I have been ſo.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Henceforth ſhall be no more,
To uſher thee to Heaven, I go before. Metricio.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Here ſweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Thou haſt been
My Poet to compoſe in facred Verſe
Spiritual Sonnets, ayres that ſuited beſt
With th'Organ, my delight at vacant hours.
Yet much adoe I had to curb that ſtrain
Of levity, thou hadſt, which too propenſe
To amorous Ditties, did profuſely vent
It ſelf (to pleaſe the humour of the time)
In vainer Raptures of Prophaning Love.
Deſiſt from this and in a pious way,
Thy ſtrayns ſhal raiſe dull thoughts to things on high.
Vertue's the ſoul of Verſe not Vanity. Phantaſio! my Muſitian, where are you?

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Here Madam, I.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Inſiſt not much on that.
That I, or ſelf-conceit, predominates
In thee too much. What is't to have a Voyce
To raiſe 'bove Ela, while the drooping ſoul
Below the baſe of abject things deſcends.
Thou tun'ſt mine Organ: Tune thy diſcordant mind
Which too phantaſtick, too too vain, diſcurres.
Mean be thy meaſure, elſe thy ſtrains are Slurres.
I want a ſervant yet: O there he ſtands;
'Tis he that ran deviſion beſt: 'Twas he
Which rounded, with a Crimſon twiſt of ſilk,
This neck with pretious Rubies once adorn'd.
But now more fulgent ſhines (with that he gave)
VVith all the ſplendours of Heaven's richer gemms.
Thanks for this favour Headſman. To forgive Gives him Money in a Purſe.
VVere ſmall requital. Here; believe and live.

sp.speaker: Headſ.
sp.p: Fair goddeſs of the Earth. Kneeling.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Thou art deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Headſm.
sp.p: O! more than woman then.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: That I deny.

sp.speaker: Headſ.
sp.l: Then faireſt Virgin, this hard heart of ſtone
Y'have mollified. Vouchſafe to take this ſword.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: Only to kiſs.

sp.speaker: Headſ.
sp.l: And cut off his right hand,
VVhich has tranſgreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: O! do not tempt to ſin.

sp.speaker: Headſ.
sp.l: Then I believe, there is a greater power
Of goodneſs in your ſoul, than all our gods.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.p: From one it is deriv'd who raigns above:

sp.speaker: Headſ.
sp.p: Him I confeſs; in him believe,—

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: And love.
O my dear Parents can you then, not love
That power immortal? not believe in him,
VVhom he adores with me, a true Believer?

sp.speaker: Mar. Fla.
sp.p: VVe do, we do, with thee, to live and die.

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: In Paradice in joy ſhall ever laſt:
Sound muſick then and let me ſing my laſt.

l.hi: Glorious Sun thy beams diſplay
To the dawning of this day.
That this payre who gave me being
May the light of truth be ſeeing.
Come dear Parents on each ſide,
Lead me now who am your guide,
That you may who gave me being
Live in bliſse, which is by ſeeing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What hideous noyſe: what winde is this?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: That which never blows to good. Behold 'tis he
Who lurking in the Idol's is ador'd.
sp.stage: Enter Devils leading Saphricius, with a Wreath of Serpents on his head: Almachius and Officers led in Chains:
sp.l: Leading a Renegade who has rejected
What you embrace: with him enchain'd the Judge
And Officers are led, his Vaſſals now. Heavenly Muſick.

div.stage: Enter Angels and Bleſſed Spirits, Valerian, Tiburtius, Maximus, Nicephorus; all with Crowns on their heads: the good goe out on the right hand, the bad on the left.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Childe what muſick's this?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: As oppoſite
To what you heard, as is this glorious Wight
To that infernal monſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And what are theſe?

sp.speaker: Cec.
sp.l: Thrice Happy ſouls, that of Valerian,
This Tiburtius: the third of Maximus,
VVhoſe candid Veſts with bloody tincture ſhine.
Laſtly that Nicephorus, who ſnatch'd a Crown
That was from Heaven deſcending on that head
VVhere now is ſeen à wreath of poyſoning ſerpents.
Come Parents follow theſe who lead the way
To endleſs happineſs: forſake that Night
And Fogg of Hell which never ſhall ſee light. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Manent Attendentes Ceciliae, to ſpeak the EPILOGUE.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Hum! ha! hum!

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.p: Palinodio what doſt mean to doe?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Uſher the Epilogue to th' Stage.

sp.speaker: Phan.
sp.l: Thou might'ſt,
VVere it a Lady.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Such I'le prove it is.
For as a Lady is cry'd up for fair
By one, by another but indifferent,
And not ſo much by a third, but infinitely
Cry'd down; So are out Playes and Epilogues.

sp.speaker: Metr.
sp.l: Yet a good Speaker i'th Concluſion,
(Which thou art not) may crye it up agen,
Therefore give way to me Phantaſio.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Yes, were the Prologue to be ſung, I would.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: Tuſh! how impertinent you are! am not I The Poet?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: What then? ſo was the Water-man,
Who puffing row'd his Prologue to the Stage
As he was won't to toyl 'gainſt tyde and winde.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Away, you all contend but to no purpoſe,
Was not the ſubject of our Play a Lady?
Whom then but Ladies do's it moſt concern?
Or whom, if not one of her ſex, doth it
Beſeem to ſpeak the Epilogue?

sp.speaker: Pha.
sp.l: 'Tis true,
I grant for Ladies this ſutes well.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Then Poet
To men make your Addreſſes.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.p: I will, hum! ha! hum!

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: More manners Sir, Ladies muſt firſt be ſerv'd. Ladies,

sp.speaker: Anguſta,
sp.l: here (who would Auguſta ſhine
In Court like to your ſelves) loſt her deſign,
Yet ſtill ambitious to be happier now,
Courting the Female ſex, I need not bow
In a ſubmiſſive way; for that would bee
To wrong our Poet, who requeſted mee,
Only to tell you, cauſe you are cry'd down
As creatures of leſs merit, leſs renown)
To ſet before your eyes what your ſex can,
At leaſt as good if not excelling man.
As conſtant, firm, as reſolute in all;
As vertuous every way, now when you ſhall
Reflect upon the Maſter-piece you've ſeen,
(Applauding that) you needs muſt have within
A Candid breſt, (which fully ſhall requite
Our Authors labour) that we call delight,
VVhich uſhers Vertue unto higher ſtrayns.
You have his ſcope, to recompenſe his pains;
But emulate his Copy,—I'th mean while
It is enough t'obtain a Lady's ſmile.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
Sh' has ſaid enough, what then is left for me?
Onely t'entreat a quick Reflexion; ſee
And well obſerve each Ladies Eye and Look,
To ſympathize with them is but to brook
VVhat pleaſes them; — Ladies example give
By clear Aſpects whether we die or live:
For we conclude,—ſo ſails our Ship to day,
By Ladies we are ſav'd, or caſt away.
